author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The Pentagon trains Ukrainian soldiers to use armed drones against Russian forces.
description: The United States is sending Switchblade drones to Ukraine, and has been teaching a group of Ukrainian soldiers who are in America on an educational assignment how to use them.
content: With the Biden administration sending dozens of armed drones to Ukraine, the Pentagon is training Ukrainian soldiers in the United States to use the weapons to attack Russian tanks and other armored vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: A Visit to ‘The Candy House’
description: Jennifer Egan’s ambitious new novel — a sequel, of sorts, to 2010’s “A Visit From the Goon Squad” — riffs on memory, authenticity and the allure of new technology.
content: THE CANDY HOUSE, by Jennifer Egan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Even Before France Votes, the French Right Is a Big Winner
description: The dominance of right-wing ideas in France’s presidential election campaign follows years of cultural wars waged successfully by conservatives on television, in social media and in think tanks.
content: PARIS — With just days to go before the first round of France’s presidential election, President Emmanuel Macron is still the odds-on favorite to make it through the political juggernaut and win a second term. But even if he does succeed, and before a single ballot is cast, another clear winner has already emerged from the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
title: Russia Is Recruiting Mercenaries and Syrians to Ukraine, Western Officials Say
description: The Kremlin is trying to find enough reinforcements to conduct the next phase of the war, according to military and intelligence officials.
content: WASHINGTON — As Russian troops retreat from northern Ukraine and focus operations on the country’s east and south, the Kremlin is struggling to scrape together enough combat-ready reinforcements to conduct a new phase of the war, according to American and other Western military and intelligence officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By András Bíró-Nagy
title: The Unsinkable Viktor Orban
description: How Hungary’s Fidesz party won.
content: BUDAPEST — Viktor Orban’s Fidesz party just won its fourth consecutive election by a landslide. As was the case four years ago, Mr. Orban’s election was not a fair contest between the Hungarian government and the opposition. Voters could vote for whomever they chose, but the playing field was tilted in favor of the current government, including campaign regulations that favored Fidesz, biased media coverage and a blurring of the line between the ruling political party and the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: June Shagaloff Alexander, School Desegregation Leader, Dies at 93
description: She helped Thurgood Marshall prepare for his Supreme Court fight and later took on de facto school segregation across the North and West.
content: June Shagaloff Alexander, whose work for the N.A.A.C.P. and its legal arm in the 1950s and ’60s put her at the forefront of the nationwide fight for school integration and made her a close confidante of civil rights figures like Thurgood Marshall and James Baldwin, died on March 29 at her home in Tel Aviv. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Two Best Friends Beat Amazon’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about one of the biggest victories for organized labor in a generation. Then, they will consider the role of unions in general, as well as the possibilities of a local student union.
content: Featured Article: “How Two Best Friends Beat Amazon” by Jodi Kantor and Karen Weise
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan and Adeel Hassan
title: European health agencies say it is ‘too early’ for second boosters for most people.
description: Additional boosters can be given to people 80 and older, who are at higher risk of severe illness if infected, the agencies said.
content: European regulators concluded on Wednesday that it is “too early” to administer second booster shots of a coronavirus vaccine to the general population in the European Union, but added that the extra doses could be given to adults aged 80 and older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Already Delayed, Yankees Opener Pushed Back One More Day
description: With rain in the forecast, the opening day matchup between the Yankees and the Red Sox was pushed to Friday.
content: Baseball’s extra-long off-season will last at least one more day for some teams, with rain postponing opening day in the Bronx and Minnesota and threatening to delay it elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Does the Amazon Union Win Portend a Comeback for Organized Labor?
description: It’s the biggest victory for organized labor in a generation. Was it a fluke or the start of a new era of labor activism?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Rounds
title: Secaucus, N.J.: The Commuter Town With a Suburban Vibe
description: This Hudson County town can at first seem like a tangle of highways. But it has enough parks and playgrounds to attract young families looking to put down roots.
content: The Hudson County suburb of Secaucus, N.J., anchors the New Jersey Meadowlands, some 30 square miles of marshland, veined with estuaries and dotted with more than a dozen towns. There was a time when people fishing in those waters told stories of reeling in a broken statue from the old Penn Station or finding a body buried under the beach grass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: The U.S. announces sanctions against Russia’s largest banks and Putin’s adult children.
description: Sberbank, the largest financial institution in Russia, and Alfa Bank, one of the country’s largest privately owned banks, will face sanctions.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies, seeking to punish Russia for the killings of Ukrainian civilians, moved on Wednesday to impose full sanctions against Russia’s largest financial institutions and to block access to U.S.-held financial assets for family members and close associates of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Meet DALL-E, the A.I. That Draws Anything at Your Command
description: New technology that blends language and images could serve graphic artists — and speed disinformation campaigns.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — At OpenAI, one of the world’s most ambitious artificial intelligence labs, researchers are building technology that lets you create digital images simply by describing what you want to see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen to Warn of ‘Enormous Economic Repercussions’ From Ukraine Invasion
description: The Treasury secretary plans to highlight risks of rising food and energy prices at a congressional hearing on Wednesday.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen plans on Wednesday to warn of major consequences for the global economy as a result of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, with both the conflict and global sanctions imposed in response to Russia’s aggression disrupting the flow of food and energy around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Renaissance Music
description: Here’s your introduction to the shining, stirring sounds of a revolutionary period in cultural history.
content: In the past we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion, symphonies, Stravinsky, trumpet, Maria Callas, Bach, the organ, mezzo-sopranos, music for dance and Wagner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $300,000 Homes in Minnesota, Maryland and Oregon
description: A 1930 Tudor Revival house in Minneapolis, a 1924 bungalow in Baltimore and a two-bedroom cottage in Salem.
content: This house is in a lively neighborhood about a 10-minute drive from downtown Minneapolis and a few blocks from a coffee shop, a public library and a grocery store. It is not far from the Grand Rounds National Scenic Byway, a popular walking and biking trail that dates to the 1930s, and the Carl W. Kroening Nature Center, on the Mississippi River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli and Ben Sisario
title: Kanye West Replaced by Swedish House Mafia and the Weeknd at Coachella
description: A little over a week before the music festival’s first weekend, West, now known as Ye, dropped out of his headlining slot.
content: Nine days before the return of Coachella, the festival has confirmed reports that Kanye West has dropped out as one of the event’s three headliners, and has been replaced by Swedish House Mafia with the Weeknd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Karim Benzema, the Surest of Sure Things, Lifts Real Madrid at Chelsea
description: Three goals confirm what should have been obvious long ago: Benzema is Real Madrid’s brain, and its heart.
content: LONDON — Luka Modric has, by this stage, seen pretty much all there is to see. He has won four Champions League titles. He has played in a World Cup final. He has spent a decade at Real Madrid, embedded among some of the finest players of his generation. He is one of the finest players of his generation. He is, most likely, neither easily impressed nor easily surprised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Michael Crowley
title: NATO Nations See Differing Paths as Ukraine War Enters Uncertain Stage
description: The alliance is examining what Ukraine needs as it tries to expel Russia from the east and how to ensure an outcome that enhances European security.
content: BRUSSELS — Faced with the prospect that the war in Ukraine will be long and grinding, NATO countries are divided on how best to manage the next stage of the conflict and the uncertain period that promises to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Inside a Campaign to Get Medicare Coverage for a New Alzheimer’s Drug
description: The Alzheimer’s Association has pushed relentlessly to get broad access to Aduhelm, despite safety risks and uncertain evidence that it helps patients.
content: The day after Medicare officials announced a preliminary decision to sharply limit coverage of the controversial new Alzheimer’s medication Aduhelm, citing its unclear benefit and serious safety risks, the nation’s most prominent Alzheimer’s advocacy organization convened its policy team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: en masse
description: This term has appeared in 188 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The term en masse has appeared in 188 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 4 in “How Scarves Became a Staple in Soccer Culture” by Alexis Benveniste:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Lananh Nguyen
title: Russia pays dollar-denominated debt in rubles, risking default, after U.S. blocks payment.
description: Credit rating agencies have indicated that payments in a currency different from the one the debt was sold in would count as a default once the grace period expired.
content: Russia’s finance ministry said on Wednesday that it had used rubles to pay about $650 million in dollar-denominated debt obligations after the U.S. government blocked access to dollars held in American banks. The move pushed the country closer to a default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Wittgenstein’s ‘Private Notebooks’ Shed Some Light on an Enigmatic Genius
description: These journals offer a view of the philosopher’s preoccupations, his sexual anguish, his struggles with work and his time in the military.
content: It’s perhaps a measure of Ludwig Wittgenstein’s genius as well as his enigma that the volume of writing about him is almost comically disproportionate to the volume of writing by him. Before his death in 1951, Wittgenstein had published a total of one book, one article and one book review (the review was written when he was an undergraduate at Cambridge). Described by another philosopher as a “spellbinding and somewhat terrifying person,” he was intensely lonely, and he dedicated his “Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus” to David Pinsent, who died in a plane crash in 1918, calling him “my first and only friend.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bee Shapiro
title: How Anya Taylor-Joy Learned to Soothe Herself
description: The actress has a challenge if you’re thinking about learning to meditate.
content: Anya Taylor-Joy, who this month shares the cover of British Vogue with Queen Elizabeth II, has brought to Hollywood her talent (see: “The Queen’s Gambit”), fashion personality (she’s a global brand ambassador for Dior Beauty) and singular perspective (see: her tip on meditation). After a childhood spent in Miami, Argentina and London, Ms. Taylor-Joy, 25, is now used to moving around every three months or so for work. Recently she was in Ireland for “The Northman,” a historical epic opening on April 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Perron
title: Bill T. Jones and Eiko Otake: Opposites Guided by ‘Too-Much-Ness’
description: These two canonical dance artists, both now 70, share a willingness to take on weighty issues.
content: Eiko Otake and Bill T. Jones are two celebrated dance artists with different styles, temperaments and cultural backgrounds. What they have in common is their willingness — hunger, really — to take on weighty issues. Otake has been illuminating the environmental damage caused by nuclear accidents. Jones is intimately connected to the struggle against racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: No Charges Against Police in Amir Locke Shooting
description: The shooting drew thousands of protesters to the streets and renewed calls for police accountability in the city where George Floyd was murdered.
content: The Minneapolis police officer who shot and killed Amir Locke, a Black man, during an early-morning raid in February at an apartment complex will not face criminal charges, prosecutors announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Fire and smoke at a Covid ward in Greece kill one and injure at least two others.
description: The episode is the latest deadly fire at a hospital ward for coronavirus patients since the pandemic began.
content: ATHENS — A fire broke out on Wednesday in a Covid ward at a hospital in Thessaloniki, a city in northern Greece, killing one person and seriously injuring at least two others, said Vassilis Vathrakoyiannis, a spokesman for Greece’s fire service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: For Prominent Women on Instagram, DMs Can Be a Cesspool of Misogyny
description: A report on direct messages sent to five women found that “abuse and harmful content is allowed to thrive” on Instagram. The platform’s parent company, Meta, said it disagreed with the report’s conclusions.
content: A look into the private direct messages of five prominent women on Instagram found a torrent of harassment, including pornographic images and threats of physical and sexual violence, while the perpetrators typically faced little to no consequences, according to a new report released Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: X’s on Bubbles
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Karen Weise
title: Biden Appears to Show Support for Amazon Workers Who Voted to Unionize
description: “By the way, Amazon, here we come. Watch,” the president said. But the White House quickly said his remarks did not mean the government would get formally involved.
content: WASHINGTON — Days after warehouse workers on Staten Island defied Amazon and successfully formed a labor union, President Biden on Wednesday threw his support behind the workers and championed their cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Anushka Patil
title: Three more Democratic representatives test positive for the coronavirus.
description: Representatives Joaquin Castro of Texas, Adam Schiff of California and Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida each said they tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday, adding to a string of recent cases of prominent Democrats on Capitol Hill and in the White House.
content: Representatives Joaquin Castro of Texas, Adam Schiff of California and Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida each said they tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday, adding to a string of recent cases of prominent Democrats on Capitol Hill and in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
title: Traces of Lives Cut Short: Bread on a Park Bench, Blood Pooled Nearby
description: The violence of war is often random. Those who suffer most are the civilians caught in the middle. Two recent deaths in Kharkiv, Ukraine, are a testament to that.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — A loaf of bread on a park bench, collecting snow. A puddle of blood nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Raphael Minder
title: Japan issues policy for entry, confusing travelers who hope to visit country.
description: The government issued a notice on Wednesday that would “lift” an entry ban on citizens of 106 nations. But consulates are still rarely issuing visas.
content: Japan announced changes on Wednesday to its entry policy for foreigners, causing confusion among travelers who hoped to enter the country. The government is issuing very few visas to foreigners, limiting the impact of the rule change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Celebrates Obama’s First White House Visit in Five Years
description: Stephen Colbert joked that he hoped “they locked the doors to keep him in.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Republicans Failed the Unvaccinated
description: Why more enthusiasm and more advertisement might have saved more lives.
content: Last fall, a group of researchers conducted a vaccine promotion experiment: They showed an advertisement to millions of U.S. YouTube users highlighting Donald Trump’s support for Covid-19 vaccines, using news footage in which the former president urged people to get vaccinated. This was a randomized controlled trial, comparing counties that were exposed to the ads to counties that weren’t, and in a new paper, the researchers claim the ads worked: Over the course of the two-and-a-half-week experiment, the 1,014 counties that were part of the campaign saw an estimated 104,036 additional vaccinations overall.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘At Night I Dream of Mariupol’: Nine Accounts of Surviving a Russian Siege
description: Mariupol, Ukraine, has been encircled by Russian forces for about a month. We have collected the statements of people who recently escaped.
content: In early March, the Russian Army encircled Mariupol, Ukraine, a southern port city on the Black Sea. A siege and relentless bombardment followed. Food and water quickly grew scarce, and gas, electricity, internet access and cellphone service became nonexistent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Ukrainians Flee the East
description: As officials warn of escalating violence, the West increases sanctions.
content: Ukrainians fled the contested regions of Luhansk and Donetsk, as Russia refocused to the east and military analysts warned of escalating violence. And Russian shelling against the Black Sea port of Mykolaiv is increasingly targeting civilian infrastructure and homes, local officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Appearing This Year at the Masters: Azaleas, Green Jackets and Inflation
description: Famously low concession prices increased a bit, injecting a small dose of the real world at Augusta National Golf Club.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The lush confines of Augusta National Golf Club, a sanctuary of sport, power and privilege, are showing a harsh economic truth: Inflation can be as invasive as kudzu weeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: What It’s Like When Your Loved Ones Won’t Leave Ukraine
description: “It’s so stressful for me to be on the outside,” said one New Yorker, who is trying to persuade her aunt, 83, to flee.
content: Jane Tuv is having so many panic attacks about her aunt, who is refusing to leave Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, that she has turned to medication. The recent horrifying discovery of civilian bodies in a Kyiv suburb has made her even more afraid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Bob Gibbs, House Republican Facing Primary Challenge in Ohio, Will Retire
description: The state’s redistricting process had drawn Mr. Gibbs into a primary fight against Max Miller, who served in the Trump White House and was endorsed by the former president.
content: Representative Bob Gibbs of Ohio announced on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election, just as early voting got underway in the state. Ohio’s redistricting process had forced Mr. Gibbs, who has served in Congress since 2011, into a Republican primary against a Trump-backed challenger, Max Miller, among others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
title: Attorneys General Threaten to Investigate N.F.L.’s Treatment of Female Employees
description: Six state attorneys general, led by New York’s Letitia James, have “grave concerns” about reports of a workplace culture within the N.F.L. that is “overtly hostile to women.”
content: The attorneys general of six states, including New York, have told the N.F.L. they have “grave concerns” about allegations of workplace harassment of women and minorities and warned the league that unless it takes steps to address the problems it could face a broad investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: New York Agrees to Expand Voting Access for People With Disabilities
description: In a settlement this week, the state agreed to make voting easier for residents with disabilities such as blindness and paralysis.
content: Voting in New York will become easier for blind and disabled residents following the settlement of a lawsuit against the New York State Board of Elections this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A New Covid Mystery
description: Why haven’t cases started rising again in the U.S.?
content: To many people’s surprise — including mine — new Covid-19 cases in the U.S. have not begun to rise. Over the past two weeks, they have held roughly steady, falling about 1 percent, even as the highly contagious BA.2 subvariant of Omicron has become the dominant form of Covid in the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Ordinary People Don’t Think Like Economists. It’s a Problem.
description: Policymakers may need to communicate better with the public.
content: Expectations matter in economics. If people think inflation will rise, they will behave in ways that will help make it rise (e.g., asking for bigger raises). If they think the economy is about to grow robustly, they will get more confident, spend more and help create the future they anticipate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 6, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 6, 2022.
content: An article on Monday about a wave of new legislation intensifying already marked differences liberal- and conservative-led parts of the country misstated the number of states in which control of the legislative chambers is split between parties. Such a split exists in two states — Minnesota and Virginia — not one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Block says a former employee downloaded data on millions of Cash App Investing customers.
description: The stolen information included the value of some customers’ portfolios and details of their stock trades, but did not involve the company’s personal payments system.
content: Sensitive information for more than eight million users of Cash App Investing — a stock trading app run by Block, the owner of the Square payments system — was exposed when a former employee downloaded corporate reports after leaving the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Tokyo Vice’ Review: Another American in Translation
description: A young Midwestern journalist comes of age on the mean streets of Tokyo in an HBO Max drama based (very loosely) on a real story.
content: “Tokyo Vice” arrives on HBO Max wrapped in layers of nostalgia, beginning with its title, which sounds like a come-on from Cinemax’s late-night heyday. It’s a reasonably tasty hand roll of yakuza drama and turn-of-the-millennium American coming-of-age tale, and it is generous with the condiments that combination promises: full-body tattoos and missing fingers, point-and-shoot cameras and bonding over the Backstreet Boys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: At least 50 people have been killed doing gig driving since 2017, report says.
description: Much attention has been paid to the risks passengers face accepting rides from Uber or Lyft, but drivers can also be in danger.
content: For nearly two years, Jassy StokesOliver crisscrossed the freeways of San Diego late at night, delivering food and dropping off riders as a gig driver for DoorDash, Lyft and Uber. She preferred working late because there was little traffic, and she never felt unsafe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Christie’s to Sell Entire Ammann Art Collection
description: Some 100 works from the siblings Doris and Thomas Ammann will be sold in May, along with their Warhol silkscreen of Marilyn Monroe, estimated at $200 million.
content: Just two weeks after announcing that it would sell an important 1964 Andy Warhol silkscreen of Marilyn Monroe from the Thomas and Doris Ammann Foundation Zurich, Christie’s on Wednesday said that it would also handle the sale of the rest of that collection, including works by Robert Ryman, Cy Twombly and Francesco Clemente.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Sarah Lawrence Cult Leader Convicted of Trafficking and Extortion
description: In 2010, Lawrence V. Ray moved into his daughter’s dormitory, gathered a circle of young followers around himself and began years of domination.
content: For a decade, Lawrence V. Ray exerted near-total control over a group of young people he met after moving into a dormitory at Sarah Lawrence College, prosecutors said. He presented himself as a mentor, isolating students from their parents, pressuring them into degrading acts and extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars from them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: Salad Secrets From Yotam Ottolenghi’s Test Kitchen
description: For his first column for the magazine, the chef shares a butter-bean salad perfect for spring.
content: I will start my first column on the pages of this magazine with an uncomfortable confession: I eat everything. I am greedy. I love to eat, so yes, I eat everything. Not literally. I won’t consume any food, obviously not; but there isn’t a kind of dish that I don’t like by definition. I eat the high end and the low end and anything in between. My saving grace, I suppose, is that at least within each category of foods, I can tell a fine example from a not-so-good one. A drawer in my home kitchen, unashamedly packed full of my top brands of instant noodles, is proof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: To Get Better, the Giants Tried a Wild Idea: (Way) More Coaches
description: Gabe Kapler’s enormous staff of 13 coaches is too many to fit in a dugout, but the unorthodox approach helped the team win 107 games in 2021. A trend was officially set.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Before the San Francisco Giants rolled to a best-in-baseball 107 wins last year, ended the Los Angeles Dodgers’ eight-year run of National League West titles and looked like geniuses, there was a seemingly wild idea that had come a year earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan’s Monkey Queen Made It Through Mating Season With Her Reign Intact
description: Yakei, the 9-year-old macaque who seized power at a preserve, played the field and mated with at least one male, all while managing to maintain her status as her troop’s alpha.
content: The reign of Japan’s monkey queen has just begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Are Your Questions About the Future of the Coronavirus?
description: We’ll bring your queries to experts and find some answers.
content: In the beginning, there was Alpha. Then Beta, Delta, Omicron and a bunch of lesser-known coronavirus variants in between. We’re used to the cycle now: Right when we think we can breathe a sigh of relief, a new variant appears with fresh mysteries and confusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Olivia Rodrigo’s Punky Heartbreak Revue
description: Two nights after she won three Grammys, the new pop star began her first tour with a show both rowdy and intimate.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — As a pop star, Olivia Rodrigo’s heritage includes precise dissectors and unruly shredders, the anguished and the angsty. Her debut album, “Sour” — one of last year’s finest releases, and one of the most promising pop arrival notices of the past few years — calmly and assuredly makes deeply interior lyrics sound like the pretext for a tussle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: How Often Do You Treat Yourself to Something Special?
description: What do you do to lift your own spirits or show yourself some love?
content: Treat yourself! What comes to mind when you read these words? (If you think of the show “Parks and Recreation,” you’re certainly not alone.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At the Frozen Four, Michigan Aims to Make Up for a Lost Year
description: No hockey team in N.C.A.A. history has had a roster like the Wolverines, who are loaded with 13 N.H.L. draft picks and are playing in a record 26th national semifinal.
content: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Mel Pearson, the University of Michigan men’s hockey coach, gestured with his hand toward a small box in his office. His voice quavered as he described his players’ hopes of winning the upcoming Frozen Four, college hockey’s premier event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Germany Strains to Wean Itself Off Gas Imports Subsidizing War
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 6, 2022.
content: “Buying Russian oil and gas is financing war crimes. Dear E.U. friends, pull the plug. Don’t be an accomplice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Sacramento Shooting Renews Calls for Tighter Gun Legislation
description: California lawmakers are promoting a package of bills, including one modeled after Texas’ controversial abortion ban.
content: Despite its strict gun laws, California is by no means spared from the pains of gun violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Katie Rogers
title: Yellen says the aim is ‘maximum pain’ for Russia without hurting the U.S. economy.
description: The Treasury secretary told a House committee that the U.S. would continue finding ways to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Wednesday that the United States would continue taking steps to cut Russia off from the global financial system in response to its invasion of Ukraine and argued that the sanctions already imposed had taken a severe toll on the Russian economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: You’re Still Being Tracked on the Internet, Just in a Different Way
description: Apple and Google are pushing privacy changes, but a shift in digital tracking is giving some platforms a bigger advertising advantage.
content: The internet industry shuddered last year when Apple introduced privacy measures for the iPhone that threatened to upend online tracking and cripple digital advertising. Google pledged similar privacy actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: Good evening. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.

title: The Growing Religious Fervor in the American Right: ‘This Is a Jesus Movement’
description: Rituals of Christian worship have become embedded in conservative rallies, as praise music and prayer blend with political anger over vaccines and the 2020 election.
content: They opened with an invocation, summoning God’s “hedge of thorns and fire” to protect each person in the dark Phoenix parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Nehemiah Persoff, Actor With a Familiar Face (and Voice), Dies at 102
description: His most prominent roles included three tenderly caring parents, but he was most associated with the dapper gangsters he portrayed in the movies and on television.
content: Nehemiah Persoff, a ubiquitous character actor whose gravelly voice and knack for conveying an air of menace magnified his portrayals of a bevy of sinister types, most notably a half-dozen Prohibition-era gangsters, died on Tuesday in San Luis Obispo, Calif. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Ambulance’ Review: Michael Bay Is Our Emergency Movie Technician
description: The action auteur’s latest opus stars Jake Gyllenhaal and Yahya Abdul-Mateen II as bank robbers who commandeer an unlikely getaway vehicle.
content: I wish someone had come with me to the screening of “Ambulance,” so I could have leaned over at a key point early in the story and whispered, “That must be the ambulance.” It’s great when movies make you feel smart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: ‘Have You Seen the Capitol Fox?’
description: Animal control officers descended on Capitol Hill after reports of lawmakers, staff members and reporters being attacked by a wild fox believed to have been nesting on the Capitol grounds.
content: WASHINGTON — For a few hours on Tuesday on Capitol Hill, attention turned briefly from the issues of the day — coronavirus aid, the war in Ukraine and the first Black woman nominated to the Supreme Court — to an urgent question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Comeback Stories, Newspaper Poetry, Smiling
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to reflect on athletes coming out of retirement, learn how to make poetry with the newspaper, reflect on a photograph from the recent Supreme Court confirmation hearings, learn a new word invented by a student and make observations about a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, from a Suburban Search to a Seoul Flower Shop
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: MESSY ROOTS: A Graphic Memoir of a Wuhanese American, by Laura Gao. (Balzer + Bray, cloth, $22.99; paper, $14.99.) The author-illustrator Gao traces her childhood move from Wuhan, China, to Coppell, Texas, and describes her adolescence in the United States. This funny debut graphic memoir grapples with queerness, anti-Asian racism and self-discovery as a diaspora kid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill and Julia Jacobs
title: Lizzo’s ‘Big Grrrls’ Asks Big Questions
description: The singer wanted a new kind of backup dancer. Along the way, she ended up making a new kind of TV show.
content: Lizzo would have rather just hired her dancers through an agency. But, as she says on the first episode of her new show that premiered on Amazon Prime Video last month, “Girls who look like me just don’t get representation.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: A Couple Walks Into City Hall
description: In a year crowded with weddings, we listen to a snapshot of those tying the knot the no-frills way.
content: It’s 2022, the year of matrimania. Roughly 2.5 million weddings are expected (a bump not seen since 1984), and other trends are wildly taking off — ceremonies for pets, weddings on weekdays, a revival of epic poofy dresses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaime Lowe
title: With ‘Stealth Politics,’ Billionaires Make Sure Their Money Talks
description: What do they actually want?
content: Billionaires are neither good nor bad for the country — at least that’s what more than half of Americans think, according to a poll published by the Pew Research Center last year. Maybe this is because they don’t know how billionaires affect their lives or what political power they wield; maybe it’s just because a billion is such an unfathomably large number. A decade or so ago, three political scientists at Northwestern University, Benjamin Page, Jason Seawright and Matthew Lacombe, set out to determine the impact that superrich Americans have on congressional and presidential policies. They weren’t starting from scratch; previous work done by another political scientist, Martin Gilens, used years of surveys of thousands of poor, middle-income and affluent Americans to show that policymakers responded almost exclusively to the preferences of that last group. Following this earlier research, Page told me recently, “I wanted to find out how much influence the truly wealthy have and what they want from government.” Page and his colleagues wanted to do a quantitative analysis of political inequality. First, however, they had to figure out where to get the data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Chocano
title: Why It’s so Satisfying to Watch a World Built From the Ground Up
description: In the fantasy depicted by the Primitive Technology YouTube channel, it is possible to bring a task to completion without interruption.
content: Early in March, a man uploaded a video to his YouTube channel. In it, he is seen emerging shirtless from a small, thatched hut, carrying a rudimentary stone hatchet. Then he walks, silently and purposefully, to a copse of narrow trees. He chops one down and carries it back to the clearing. He repeats this action until he has assembled a pile of timber. We watch as he demolishes his old, thatched workshop and builds a new one, twice the size. The man does not explain what he is doing as he frames the structure or as he thatches the roof with palm fronds and vines; in fact, he doesn’t talk at all. If you turn on the closed captioning, you can see descriptions of his actions, but only very general ones: “lashing rafters,” “putting rafters in place,” etc. There is no music. There’s no extradiegetic sound at all — just the forest’s chirping melodies and the rustling and chopping and hammering of insects, birds, wind in leaves, stone on wood. After completing the shelter, the man builds a pit and starts a fire by rubbing sticks together, to ward off mosquitoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Shanghai’s Unsparing Lockdown
description: Chinese authorities have deployed a familiar harsh playbook to snuff out the outbreak — no matter the cost.
content: As the highly contagious Omicron variant rips through Shanghai, Chinese authorities have deployed a familiar draconian playbook to try to snuff out the outbreak — no matter the cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Tim Ryan Struggles to Reach Ohio’s Exhausted Majority
description: Mr. Ryan, the Ohio Democrat running for Senate, has been listening to white working-class voters. Whether they are listening to him and the Democratic Party is the question.
content: NILES, OHIO — Representative Tim Ryan won re-election in 2020. But in one sharply personal way, he lost, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich, Jillian Steinhauer, Martha Schwendener, Max Lakin and John Vincler
title: Art We Saw This Spring
description: From our critics, reviews of closed gallery shows around New York City.
content: Born in Brooklyn in 1935, Mel Leipzig studied painting at Cooper Union and Yale, where his interest in realist portraiture was discouraged by such eminences as Josef Albers. But he stuck to his vision, and since 1970 he’s been chronicling the lives and contexts of friends and neighbors in Trenton, N.J. — where he taught for 45 years — with precision, empathy and a volume of detail that would overwhelm a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: 196 Sailings and Counting: The ‘Cult Cruisers’ Are Back on the Ships
description: For this devoted group of cruise fanatics, most of them retirees, the aim is to almost never touch dry land. “We were really homesick for our second home,” says one.
content: On a Wednesday morning in March, Rita Deitchman, 74, was wearing a Royal Caribbean diamond necklace, earrings and bracelets as she perched on the boardwalk of the cruise company’s 6,988-passenger ship, Wonder of the Seas, in San Juan, P.R.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Steinberger
title: How the ​​‘Homeless Billionaire’ Became a Philosopher King
description: Money can buy influence over nearly anything in the world — including in the world of ideas.
content: “Just close your eyes. We’re almost there. Well, not quite. But soon.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 7, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 7, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about Elon Musk joining Twitter’s board after becoming the company’s biggest shareholder misstated the year that he mused in a tweet about taking Tesla, the electric car company he founded, private. It was 2018, not 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: With New Museum, Officials Give Techno the Stamp of Approval
description: The municipal authorities in Frankfurt are backing the Museum of Modern Electronic Music, as Germany’s policymakers’ embrace clubbing as an economic force and part of the country’s heritage.
content: FRANKFURT — These days, this German city is known as a staid financial capital and home to the European Central Bank. But in the 1980s, it held another, more underground distinction, as a hub for Europe’s budding techno scene. Although the electronic music genre’s origins are largely in Detroit, Frankfurt’s clubs were among the first to bring the sound to Europeans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Why Russian Sanctions Won’t Stop Putin
description: A former head of NATO’s armed forces, Gen. Philip Breedlove, makes the case for what will stop the war instead.
content: The Russian invasion of Ukraine is in its sixth week. Atrocities committed by Russian troops have reached new levels; in Bucha, recent photos show dead, unarmed civilians lining the streets. The harrowing scenes have prompted NATO leaders to consider taking new measures against Russia, namely to equip Ukraine with more weapons and impose more sanctions on Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Volodymyr Zelensky’s address to the U.N.
content: Addressing the U.N. Security Council yesterday via a video link, Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, accused Russia of a litany of horrors and questioned whether a world body that takes no action to stop a war serves any purpose. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Morning newsletter explores why U.S. cases have not yet started rising again.
description: The Morning newsletter on Wednesday focused on the state of the virus in the United States. Here is an excerpt.
content: The Morning newsletter on Wednesday focused on the state of the virus in the United States. Here is an excerpt.

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Avelar
title: El Salvador’s New Law on Gangs Raises Censorship Fears
description: A measure punishing the sharing of information about gangs is so vague, critics say, that virtually anyone can be arrested for speaking or writing about them, putting journalists in the cross hairs.
content: El Salvador’s Congress passed a measure late Tuesday to punish anyone who shares information about gangs with up to 15 years in prison, a move that observers say could lead to the censorship of journalists and more mass detentions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: A makeup artist recognized this Bucha victim’s picture by her manicure.
description: The woman, Iryna Filkina, had worked at a heating plant. She had contacted the makeup artist for help being more beautiful and fashionable.
content: Among the distressing pictures of dead bodies in Bucha, the Kyiv suburb where Russian forces are accused of carrying out atrocities against Ukrainian citizens, one in particular stood out to Anastasiia Subacheva, a makeup artist from the nearby city of Gostomel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: In South Korea, Ukraine War Revives the Nuclear Question
description: Seoul abandoned a covert program in the 1970s, but some argue it is time for the country to embrace its nuclear ambitions and safeguard against a Russia-style invasion.
content: SEOUL — When Ukraine gave up its nuclear weapons in the 1990s, experts debated whether the decision would make the country safer or more vulnerable to an invasion from Moscow, its nuclear-armed neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Countries have expelled 120 Russian spies since the war in Ukraine started.
description: Despite the purge of intelligence officers, former officials cautioned that Moscow would have other ways to collect information and that the efforts would have little impact on the war in Ukraine.
content: Governments around the world have kicked out some 120 Russian intelligence officers since the invasion of Ukraine as part of the larger effort to expel Moscow’s diplomats, according to a senior Western intelligence official.

title: Matthew Broderick, a star of Broadway’s ‘Plaza Suite,’ has tested positive for the coronavirus.
description: Broderick’s positive test result comes as coronavirus cases have once again been rising in New York City, and a number of Broadway shows have been affected
content: Matthew Broderick, who is now starring on Broadway in a revival of the Neil Simon comedy “Plaza Suite,” has tested positive for the coronavirus. He did not perform Tuesday night, and it is not clear when he will return to the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Anna Schaverien and David F. Gallagher
title: Koch Industries’ Bet on Batteries
description: The company is plugging $30 million into a start-up co-founded by one of Silicon Valley’s favorite scientists.
content: Charles Koch — the C.E.O. of Koch Industries, the sprawling energy and commodities conglomerate — has funded conservative groups that raise doubts about climate change, part of the considerable political influence that his family fortune wields. Over the past few years, Koch has also been a big investor in batteries — a key technology in the global effort to cut carbon emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Says It Secretly Removed Malware Worldwide, Pre-empting Russian Cyberattacks
description: The operation is the latest effort by the Biden administration to thwart actions by Russia by making them public before Moscow can strike.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States said on Wednesday that it had secretly removed malware from computer networks around the world in recent weeks, a step to pre-empt Russian cyberattacks and send a message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Abortion Pills, Once a Workaround, Are Now a Target
description: In advance of a Supreme Court decision, states are proposing new restrictions and heavier criminal penalties on medication abortion.
content: Last year, after Texas passed its strict abortion ban, surgical abortions in the state dropped by half. Many women found a workaround: pills. The week the law took effect, requests for medication abortion shot up to 138 a day from 11 a day at just one service that delivers the pills by mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: The Capitol Fox, Euthanized After Attacks, Tests Positive for Rabies
description: The tale of a wild fox on Capitol Hill had captivated those who live and work there. Then a congressman and several others were bitten, the fox was captured and she turned out to be rabid.
content: WASHINGTON — A fox that bit at least nine people on Capitol Hill, possibly including a congressman, tested positive for rabies on Wednesday, according to city health officials, after she had been euthanized in a grim turn in an episode that had briefly captivated those who live and work around Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

title: More Russians Consider Costs of War in Ukraine as Casualties Mount
description: Many Russians have been in the dark about their country’s losses. As news of more Russian deaths arrives, the reactions range from anger at the Kremlin to parroting the state’s messaging that blames “Nazis’’ in Ukraine.
content: Ivan Kononov, a senior lieutenant in the Russian marines, loved to cook. He made Italian food for his unit in the field, his brother said, and traded rations for spices when he was serving in Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Help Wanted: Adjunct Professor, Must Have Doctorate. Salary: $0.
description: After protests, U.C.L.A. took down a job posting that offered no pay. But it turns out colleges often expect Ph.D.s to work for free.
content: The job posting for an assistant adjunct professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, set high expectations for candidates: A Ph.D. in chemistry or biochemistry, a strong teaching record at the college level, and three to five letters of recommendation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Christian Smalls Is Leading a Labor Movement in Sweats and Sneakers
description: “If I was to run for president, I would look just like this,” said Mr. Smalls, the president of the Amazon Labor Union.
content: On Friday morning, before the results were released from a vote that would mark the first union victory at Amazon, Christian Smalls dressed as he would just about any other day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Europe is weighing a ban on Russian coal. Here’s what that could mean.
description: The European Union relies on Russia for almost half its coal, but new contracts with other countries could ease the transition.
content: European leaders, seeking to punish Russia for its role in suspected atrocities carried out in Ukraine, are zeroing in on a ban on coal as the imported energy source that would be the easiest to replace.
source.name: The New York Times

title: House Hunting in Portugal: A Villa Nestled in a Garden Outside Lisbon
description: With its strict preservation laws and limited inventory, the coastal area of Comporta is trying to squeeze in as many new vacation homes as it can.
content: This four-bedroom house with a thatched straw roof is nestled amid umbrella pines and ancient olive trees a few miles from a 40-mile stretch of Atlantic Ocean beaches in Comporta, a coastal area in Portugal’s south-central Alentejo region, about an hour south of Lisbon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lakers Eliminated From Playoff Contention
description: The loss to the Phoenix Suns on Tuesday sealed their fate. It’s the second time the Lakers will miss the postseason since LeBron James joined the team in 2018.
content: The Los Angeles Lakers’ last glimmer of hope for this season is gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Zipkin
title: Vertical Farms Expand as Demand for Year-Round Produce Grows
description: The industry is expected to grow to $9.7 billion worldwide by 2026, but it faces challenges, including high energy costs, technological limitations and the ability to scale.
content: A recently constructed 95,000-square-foot warehouse in Compton, Calif., ticks off all the boxes for the booming storage industry: 32-foot-high ceilings, a secure truck court and access to truck routes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Hard-liner Who Led Crackdown on Protests Is Favorite to Run Hong Kong
description: John Lee, who spent his career in Hong Kong’s security services, is likely to continue Beijing’s emphasis on political stability above all else.
content: HONG KONG — John Lee rose through the ranks of Hong Kong’s security services, earning a reputation as a hard-liner by crushing the city’s 2019 protest movement and curbing dissent as the city’s No. 2 official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Vimal Patel
title: Grand Jury Indicts Nurse, but Not Jail Officers, in Death of Black Man
description: The nurse was working at a North Carolina jail in 2019 when officers restrained John Neville on his stomach for more than 12 minutes after he fell from his bed, according to an autopsy report.
content: A grand jury this week indicted a nurse but declined to indict five former detention officers in the death of a Black inmate who repeatedly exclaimed “I can’t breathe” as the officers tried unsuccessfully to remove his handcuffs at a North Carolina jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia, Cora Engelbrecht and Eric Schmitt
title: Civilians Flee Eastern Ukraine as Signs Point to Stepped-Up Russian Attack
description: Alarmed by reports of atrocities near Kyiv, many residents of Ukraine’s east, now suffering the brunt of Russian force, are getting out while they can.
content: Spurred by reports of Russian atrocities outside Ukraine’s capital, and alarmed at signs that Russia’s invasion force is about to escalate assaults in eastern Ukraine, many civilians in that region are fleeing while they can, officials said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Document the War Crimes in Ukraine
description: Posterity must know what really happened in Ukraine. Justice must be given a chance.
content: The apocalyptic images of bodies sprawled in the mud among twisted tanks, charred walls and splintered trees in Bucha and other Ukrainian cities speak to the brutality of the war that Vladimir Putin started. The knowledge that more such horrors, many more, will be revealed as Russian troops retreat cries out for a reckoning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: Following Our Audience to Telegram
description: The Times created a designated channel on the most popular messaging service in Russia to deliver news about the war in Ukraine.
content: Late on the first Friday night in March, Vindu Goel, an audience editor for The New York Times, sent an email to his colleagues with the subject line: “If NYTimes.com gets blocked in Russia … ”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Marlise Simons
title: Amid talk of war crimes in Ukraine, there are lessons from the Balkan bloodshed.
description: The indictment of Slobodan Milosevic, the president of Yugoslavia, was a seminal moment in legal history. But prosecuting war crimes remains a steep climb.
content: The evidence of apparent atrocities in Ukraine, with civilians executed in the suburbs of Kyiv, brings to mind another European horror: the bloody Balkan wars of the 1990s and the sometimes fraught, yearslong effort to bring those responsible to justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tornado Warnings Sweep the South After 2 Deaths
description: The National Weather Service issued warnings for several states as nearly 14 million people faced an enhanced risk of severe weather on Wednesday.
content: Severe weather continued to rip across the Southeast on Wednesday, a day after a ferocious cycle of storms that was blamed for at least two deaths on Tuesday. Nearly 14 million people were in the path of severe weather that forecasters said could produce more tornadoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Is 30 Minutes of Exercise a Day Enough?
description: Science says you may need less exercise than you think to live a long and healthy life.
content: For anyone interested in the relationship between exercise and living longer, one of the most pressing questions is how much we really need to stay healthy. Is 30 minutes a day enough? Can we get by with less? Do we have to exercise all in one session, or can we spread it throughout the day? And when we’re talking about exercise, does it have to be hard to count?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed minutes showed ‘many’ officials in favor of a big rate increase.
description: Notes from the March meeting, at which it raised rates by a quarter of a percentage point, showed officials gearing up to pull back economic support quickly as they try to tame inflation.
content: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s March meeting showed that central bankers were preparing to shrink their portfolio of bond holdings imminently while raising interest rates “expeditiously,” as the central bank tries to cool off the economy and rapid inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rima Suqi
title: In an Orange Grove in India, a Celebration of Harvest and Love
description: Before competing at the World Cup of shooting in Lima, Peru, the former Olympian Shagun Chowdhary gathered friends for a night of dancing at her family farm.
content: “The longer the party, the happier I am,” says the Indian trapshooter Shagun Chowdhary by phone from Narangah, her family’s organic fruit and vegetable farm on the outskirts of Jaipur, India, where she had recently hosted her first big event. Although guests had come to toast the newly married couple Neha Luthra and Samarth Kasliwal (son of the late jeweler and Gem Palace co-owner Munnu Kasliwal), Chowdhary had her own reason to celebrate: The previous week, she’d qualified for the ISSF’s shotgun World Cup in Lima, Peru. (She ended up placing fourth in her event at the competition, which comes to an end tomorrow.) It was yet another milestone for the 38-year-old athlete who, in 2012, became the first woman to represent India in the sport at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Furillo and Thomas Fuller
title: Sacramento Police Describe Weekend Shooting as a Gang Firefight
description: The police said that at least five gunmen were part of the downtown shooting that killed six people.
content: SACRAMENTO — The Sacramento Police Department said on Wednesday that “gang violence” was at the center of the shooting that killed six people and wounded 12 over the weekend and that at least five gunmen were involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Ulysses Jenkins: Journeys of a Video Griot
description: He changed how artists use video, exposing how the medium reinforced racial stereotypes, then using it as a conduit for global community. At the Hammer Museum, he gets his due.
content: LOS ANGELES — “Two-Zone Transfer” opens with a shot of the artist Ulysses Jenkins waiting for the bus. “Two-zone transfer,” he tells the driver as his coins clink into the slot. The video ends as he disembarks. In between, however, the journey is a restive tour of what Jenkins calls the “same old basic image problems” that have haunted African Americans from the start. In a smoky, surreal visitation, Jenkins encounters three Black men dressed in dark suits, cotton gloves and masks of Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford smeared with shoe polish. They are minstrels, and they stage a capsule history of minstrelsy in popular entertainment. “As far as we’re concerned,” says one, in a disorienting bit of racial cosplay, “your culture needs our interpretation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Iowa Man Who Faked His Death to Avoid Trial Is Arrested
description: Jacob Greer, 28, had been on the run since 2016, fleeing trial on child sexual abuse imagery charges.
content: After nearly six years on the run, an Iowa man who slipped out of an ankle monitor and faked his own death has been arrested 1,700 miles from his grandmother’s home, where he had been awaiting trial on child sexual abuse imagery charges, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Mystical Character
description: Damon Gulczynski’s Wednesday puzzle offers a look between the lines.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Howdy, solvers. Some of you might recognize my byline from the Spelling Bee Forum, but those of you who have been around for a while might remember that I wrote some Wordplay columns a year or so ago. I’ve mostly worked in the background since, although I was recently tapped again to give some insight on a puzzle. I’m glad to report that it’s an excellent one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden White House Keeps Student Loan Payments at Bay Amid Inflation
description: The administration is in a tight spot as fast inflation makes households unhappy. Trying to offset price pain can risk stoking demand.
content: President Biden, under fire for rapid inflation and looking for ways to help cushion rising costs for households, extended a moratorium on student debt payments through August. While politically popular with Mr. Biden’s party, the move drew criticism for adding a small measure of oomph to the very inflation the government is trying to tame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Jamel Shabazz: Proud Street Culture on Display
description: He chronicled the fashion shifts of stylish young Black New Yorkers in the 1980s and ’90s in photographs celebrated at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.
content: When Jamel Shabazz was a teenager in Brooklyn, a gang member opened his eyes to the power of photography. Shabazz was introduced by a junior high school friend to one of the Jolly Stompers. During Shabazz’s visit to his apartment, the Stomper, who was only 18 or 19 himself, took out thick photo albums with pictures of his confederates. “They had a style I had never seen before,” Shabazz said. “They wore suits, and their pants had creases. You would never know they were in a gang.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Governor Targets Migrants in Anticipation of Influx at Border
description: The end of a pandemic-related federal policy is expected to lead to a surge in immigration. Gov. Greg Abbott said he would send migrants who volunteered to the steps of the U.S. Capitol.
content: HOUSTON — Gov. Greg Abbott said on Wednesday that Texas would set up checkpoints to stop commercial vehicles coming from Mexico and would charter buses to bring migrants released by federal agents north to Washington, ushering in a new phase in an increasingly pitched political clash over immigration policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: ‘The Sport of Love’: Ping-Pong, the Great Equalizer
description: Wally Green has played everywhere from Brooklyn to Pyongyang, becoming a beloved American ambassador for table tennis — and international understanding — in the process.
content: A Ping-Pong ball, nearly as light as a penny, rescued Wally Green. It sent him to China, Japan and North Korea. It took him to a nightclub in Hong Kong where, amid a whoosh of theater smoke and razzle-dazzle lights, a pool table was plucked from the floor and suspended in midair to make way for an exhibition Ping-Pong match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Iman and Stacey Abrams Honored at 15 Percent Pledge Gala
description: The pledge seeks to get retailers to set aside 15 percent of their shelf space to Black-owned brands.
content: “Tonight to me feels like the Black Met Gala,” said Shanée Benjamin, an art director and illustrator. “It’s just beautiful, so many people here, so many designers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Government in Crisis After Senior Lawmaker Quits Coalition
description: Idit Silman, the de facto government whip, left the coalition, depriving the government of a parliamentary majority. But her move does not mean the opposition can force new elections, at least for now.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s fragile government was thrown into crisis on Wednesday after a senior lawmaker quit the coalition, leaving it without a majority in Parliament and auguring a return to the political instability that has hobbled the country in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Benjamin Weiser
title: Justice Dept. Charges Russian Oligarch With Violating Sanctions
description: The department also unveiled additional measures meant to neutralize Russian money laundering and disrupt online criminal networks.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said on Wednesday that it had charged a Russian oligarch with violating U.S. sanctions and unveiled additional measures intended to counter Russian money laundering and disrupt online criminal networks in an effort to enforce financial penalties on Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Pinterest bans climate misinformation from posts and ads.
description: The virtual pinboard service will remove content that denies climate change after also blocking ads about politics, weight loss and anti-vaccine sentiment.
content: Pinterest will prohibit ads and posts that feature climate misinformation in its latest attempt to block harmful content on its virtual pinboard service, the company said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Jon Scheyer Has Been Waiting, and Working
description: Mike Krzyzewski’s announcing his retirement as Duke’s coach a year in advance allowed Jon Scheyer to focus on recruiting. He has landed top players as Duke looks to keep its blue blood status.
content: NEW ORLEANS — After coaching the final game of his storied career, Duke’s Mike Krzyzewski and his wife, Mickie, climbed into a golf cart in a hallway near the Superdome’s press room late Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: An Afrofuturism Festival Brings an Energy Shift to Carnegie Hall
description: The inaugural event explored a movement about denial and transcendence in the most institutional music hall in New York City.
content: The first time Sun Ra and his Arkestra played Carnegie Hall, in April 1968, they were shrouded in darkness for most of the show. The critic John S. Wilson, reviewing for The New York Times, was flummoxed. Wilson considered himself a Sun Ra fan, but he couldn’t fathom why, on the country’s most prestigious stage, the cosmic keyboardist, bandleader and philosopher was keeping his ensemble’s wondrous “array of odd instruments” and “colorful costumes” out of view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar, Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky Dies at 75; Ultranationalist Russian Politician
description: His antics kept him at center stage in Russia for three decades, and his once fringe views on imperial expansion had gone mainstream with the invasion of Ukraine.
content: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, a veteran Russian politician who served as both ultranationalist firebrand and clownish provocateur in the Kremlin’s carefully managed political system, died on Wednesday. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Doris Derby, Civil Rights Era Photographer, Dies at 82
description: She was an artist who was studying anthropology when she became an activist in the civil rights movement and a rare woman to document Black life in photos.
content: Doris Derby, an educator, artist, activist and civil rights era photographer who turned her camera away from the violence of the times to capture the quieter moments of the movement, and in so doing documented the transformation of Black life in rural Mississippi, died on March 28 in Atlanta. She was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: The Boston Marathon has barred runners from Russia and Belarus.
description: The marathon, one of the world’s top distance races, joins a long list of events from the sports world and beyond that have excluded Russians because of their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Runners from Russia and Belarus will not be allowed to compete in the Boston Marathon this month, the race organizers said on Wednesday — another example of the countries’ deepening isolation over the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: New Russian Land Mine Poses Special Risk in Ukraine
description: The sophisticated POM-3 mine was discovered last week by Ukrainian bomb technicians, as Russia contaminates much of the country with unexploded munitions.
content: WASHINGTON — Russian forces in Ukraine appear to be using a new type of weapon as they step up attacks on civilian targets: an advanced land mine equipped with sensors that can detect when people walk nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: Baseball Is Dying. The Government Should Take It Over.
description: A modest proposal for saving our national pastime.
content: Opening day of the Major League Baseball season, which falls on Thursday after being delayed for a week by a labor dispute, is as good an occasion as any for fans of the game to come to terms with certain hard facts. I am talking, of course, about the inevitable future in which professional baseball is nationalized and put under the authority of some large federal entity — the Library of Congress, perhaps, or more romantically, the National Park Service.

title: In the Ukrainian port city of Mykolaiv, residential areas are increasingly under threat.
description: Civilian infrastructure and homes in the Black Sea city have increasingly been targeted after weeks of Russian shelling, local officials and soldiers say.
content: Residential areas of Ukraine’s Black Sea port of Mykolaiv have been under near constant bombardment for days, according to local officials, the latest escalation in a southern city as Russian forces have increasingly shifted focus to the region and the east of the country.

author: By Ali Watkins and Troy Closson
title: Shootings Rise in New York, Coloring Perceptions of City’s Safety
description: Homicides were down in the first quarter, but the statistics don’t stem anxiety that the city might be regressing to a violent past.
content: Shootings in New York City rose during 2022’s first quarter compared with the same period last year, even as homicides declined, police officials said Wednesday afternoon, the continuation of a drumbeat of violence that emerged early in the pandemic, and has not ebbed with the virus.

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What Will Motivate More Parents to Vaccinate Their Kids?
description: They’re not necessarily misinformed. Some are just worried.
content: Almost a year ago, when the Covid vaccine first became available for teenagers, I talked to parents who had received the vaccine themselves, but were hesitant about their kids getting the shot. Most parents I spoke to cited concerns that were based in misinformation or disinformation, like the idea that the vaccine might damage their daughters’ future fertility, a notion not backed up by evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Weinert-Kendt
title: ‘Not Understanding Is Really Satisfying’: A Director Keeps You Thinking
description: Lileana Blain-Cruz, a “master of curating chaos,” is making her Broadway directing debut with a revival of Thornton Wilder’s comedy of human survival, “The Skin of Our Teeth.”
content: The first thing that gets you is the laugh. It can pop up like a jack-in-the-box or tumble out in waves in the midst of conversation with the director Lileana Blain-Cruz, who is making her Broadway directing debut with an ambitious revival of Thornton Wilder’s “The Skin of Our Teeth” at Lincoln Center’s Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: A New Surge of Ukrainians at U.S. Border
description: More than 2,000 have reached the U.S. border with Mexico, where an expected spike in migration from other countries will raise tough questions: Who gets priority?
content: TIJUANA, Mexico — More than 2,000 Ukrainians have made their way to the U.S. border from Mexico over the past 10 days, joining desperate migrants from around the world in what officials expect could become a major border surge as pandemic restrictions are lifted and the continuing fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine reaches America’s shores.

title: Judge Finds Man Not Guilty in First Jan. 6 Acquittal
description: The defendant, Matthew Martin, had claimed the police let him into the Capitol during last year’s pro-Trump riot. The judge agreed.

title: Ed Sheeran Wins ‘Shape of You’ Plagiarism Case
description: The singer “neither deliberately, nor subconsciously” stole from another songwriter when writing his 2017 hit, a British judge ruled.

author: By David Gardner
title: Knicks Rookie Quentin Grimes Can’t Stop Scrolling, Either
description: A dolphin trend on TikTok made his name on the internet. Now Grimes, 21, is trying to make his mark at Madison Square Garden.
content: Quentin Grimes was leaning on his kitchen island, snacking on tortilla chips and scrolling through TikTok. It was October 2020, and he was a couple of months away from starting his junior season of men’s basketball at the University of Houston. On his TikTok feed, he encountered video after video of people imitating dolphins and bumping their bodies into friends and strangers. Grimes couldn’t stop laughing, so he decided to jump into the deep end of the trend.
